X-Plane 12 is Lego, while MSFS (2020) is Playmobil - let me explain;

Both are - by now - excellent Simulator Platforms that excel in their own way. Both have their benefits and downsides, both are well supported by mods, tools, and utilities. And most importantly, both can be serious fun. But X-Plane is snappy, direct and honest, and much like the Lego Brick on the floor it can hurt and annoy you. MSFS on the other hand delivers a smooth surface, with excellent and bold visuals out of the box, and makes up for what it lacks in depth, even with 3rd party software already considered. 

I don't want to take sides, I can enjoy both and I was annoyed by both, and frankly - I spent way too much money on both. But I (again) feel more at home within X-Plane 12 than I do with MSFS or even MSFS 2024. Simply because behind the wall of firstly overwhelming functionality, everything is logical, structured, and functional to me. No lack of feature has to hide behind a fancy UI mask - it's unappologetic in good ways as much as in bad ways. And I respect that. 

Funnily enough, after the mess XP12 was in its early access to me, I've sworn to settle down with MSFS, then after a year of release I bought 2024 and was equally disappointed, which again drew me back to XP12, as my MSFS install was already deleted. And likelihood of going full circle once more is definitely given. 

So, if you're
* not afraid of basic UI's with high functionality,
* keen to mod your experience to your liking,
* accept longer development times in exchange for actual feedback driven improvements,
* and accept a little less graphical fidelity over a little more depth, 
I can recommend XP12 to you. 

If any one of the above seems odd to you, you'll most likely have more fun in MSFS - and that's said without any sort of elitist note, because it's completely fine.

As a commercial pilot, I can say X-Plane 12 is very good for airline sim prep‚Äîit helps a lot. The flight dynamics and systems modeling make it useful for practicing procedures.

That said, there are some bugs that can be annoying. I understand the limitations of the sim, I  give it a positive review.

I've been flying X-Plane since XP9. Look in all reality there has always been a comparative between MS Flight sim and X-Plane since the start but IMO X-plane has a lot of Pros and perhaps maybe few cons. The biggest thing is that you need to know before purchasing whether you're trying to fly for the Enhancement of Graphics, or if you're looking for something more realistic and less "Arcade" X-Plane offers ALOT of realistic aerodynamic/aircraft Physics and it is by far THE Most accurate of all. Take for instance an ILS approach here vs MSFS. X-Plane mimics the small movement input that you'd experience in a real world situation. MSFS unless you have Extreme weather, ANY PLANE FEELS LEGIT LIKE A LASER BEAM TO THE RUNWAY. This is maybe the reason why Xplane has a professional version that accredited flight school use rather than just using MSFS. Surely if we talk about graphics, the Cloud engine on MSFS makes it seem like it surpasses XP12 but in al reality, I would challenge that XP12 is really not that far behind. Ground texture sure, MSFS is great at using GMAP in order to generate buildings and  structures but if you take a step back and look at the big picture, this is where you determine whether youre flight just for the arcade aspect of it or for the realism of the sim. I Hope this helps you guys choosing the sim of preference. Enjoy it!

I've been playing X-Plane since version 9. It's just become small increments or refinements. Graphically, the game looks dated compared to MSFS 2020/24 and what I mean by that is, the graphics compare to Microsoft Flight Simulator X which came out in 2006. It also has a basic UI and the game runs poorly compared to MSFS 2020/24 which looks 10x better. I shouldn't be averaging 32FPS in 4K with everything set to max with a 9800X3D, 64GB of 6000Mhz RAM, RTX 5080 and a Gen 4 Samsung NVME.

What I question as a player are the choices the X-Plane team chose. The planes look nice and shiny on the outside like they were delivered from the factory and received 7 coats of Mothers car wax. Yet inside the cockpit of the Cessna and the windshield looks weather beaten with scratches. It makes viewing things and the glare it creates at night difficult to see. I am not a pilot but I have flown with friends who were. In Florida, a typical Cessna 172 the paint looks dull and weather beaten but the windshield looks clear. So here's my problem with this approach, you created shiny exteriors that make the planes look new but you did the opposite for the planes windshield.

There really isn't the much to engage the player whereas MSFS caters to a wider audience and you can tailor the difficulty to your experience level. There isn't a perfect product but the  X-Plane team needs to do something different with X-Plane 13 besides having nicer weather and shiny planes. I give it a 3.5/5 stars.

Here's what I would like to see even though they will never read this. Please include mapping software out of the box, like Bing, Apple or Google Maps. Incorporate it into the game. If there's a licensing fee, then increase the price of X-Plane 13 or whatever the next one is called.

Also, widen the net to bring in more customers. You can do that similar to what Microsoft did with their product. Include a career mode, adventures, more planes, more scenarios. Make it easy for the casual general aviation fan to quickly create a flight plan to go from one airport to another. That is what makes Flight Simulator 2020/24 so engaging.

I've been playing X-Plane since version 9. It's just become small increments or refinements. Graphically, the game looks dated compared to MSFS 2020/24 and what I mean by that is, the graphics compare to Microsoft Flight Simulator X which came out in 2006. It also has a basic UI and the game runs poorly compared to MSFS 2020/24 which looks 10x better. I shouldn't be averaging 32FPS in 4K with everything set to max with a 9800X3D, 64GB of 6000Mhz RAM, RTX 5080 and a Gen 4 Samsung NVME.

What I question as a player are the choices the X-Plane team chose. The planes look nice and shiny on the outside like they were delivered from the factory and received 7 coats of Mothers car wax. Yet inside the cockpit of the Cessna and the windshield looks weather beaten with scratches. It makes viewing things and the glare it creates at night difficult to see. I am not a pilot but I have flown with friends who were. In Florida, a typical Cessna 172 the paint looks dull and weather beaten but the windshield looks clear. So here's my problem with this approach, you created shiny exteriors that make the planes look new but you did the opposite for the planes windshield.

There really isn't the much to engage the player whereas MSFS caters to a wider audience and you can tailor the difficulty to your experience level. There isn't a perfect product but the  X-Plane team needs to do something different with X-Plane 13 besides having nicer weather and shiny planes. I give it a 3.5/5 stars.

Here's what I would like to see even though they will never read this. Please include mapping software out of the box, like Bing, Apple or Google Maps. Incorporate it into the game. If there's a licensing fee, then increase the price of X-Plane 13 or whatever the next one is called.

Also, widen the net to bring in more customers. You can do that similar to what Microsoft did with their product. Include a career mode, adventures, more planes, more scenarios. Make it easy for the casual general aviation fan to quickly create a flight plan to go from one airport to another. That is what makes Flight Simulator 2020/24 so engaging.
